comments.commentBody: Quadrupling the pixel density of the display is in no way a "modest" upgrade, as will become ultra-obvious to anyone who's actually seen or used the device.

A lot of people don't know that the man who donates big money to Newt's campaign is playing politic by keeping Newt in the race to keep Rick from competing head to head vs. Mitt, so Mitt can get to finish line.  Having said that, It would be interesting, if it's a two men race.

@walterrhett,

Are you implied that John McCain supported Mitt Romney is also a race card? When is supporting or endorsed someone that share your value is a race card in this society?

I think race will trump ideological and religious biases amongst the far right conservatives.  They will vote against Obama, and the GOP knows that, so Romney is secure there.  If, however, Santorum pulls a Nadar and runs a third party campaign, then those folks might just make a statement and vote against Romney as well.  And I think Santorum has the personality to consider a third party race.  He knows the GOP establishment will be against him in 2016.  But would Romney co-opt him by picking him as VP?  There does seem to be too much bad blood between them, but this is politics.  More fun ahead!

The 2nd half of my original (first comment) was literally a line-by- line parody of NYT comment opposing Obama. I reversed its terms (like algebra!), added some terms ( I do dearly love long, intricate, complex, periodic sentences) but mirrored the intent and attack to try to gain insight into how and why its right wing construction is so effective and has so much staying power--and to see if the style, strings of broilerplate, trigger words (masters, his friends, "wants to give") could be adapted.

I'm a writer; often my thought approach is to explore the craft and its construction for ideas. It's technical, but it generates ideas as I see how clauses are assembled, verbs are tied to nouns, and voice and logic (or illogic!) flow.

An inside secret: my favorite construction right now is the (!), I use it in every comment! (Lo!)

The poll Q was pure curiousity (inspired by twitter!) after reading a rant about how . . . blah, blah. I wondered why others thought. Thanks for weighing in.

Romney, mired in his shape-shifting disconnect, but well-heeled, having experienced his own 6 year quadmire, is hoping for an even bigger backlash against the President. Given his skills not in winning votes, but in focusing and funding negative campaigns with unlimited outside money by which the other guy is routed from the field, Romney and his takeover team and advisors hope the negative space of race (double pun: as in art, a defining perspective of point of view; as an American icon with a powerful subterranean staying power and a covering history of denial), will solidify to prevent the President from capitalizing on Romney's failures and his budget busting policies which will increase the debt to fund defense for his warmongering masters as our safety net funds, pay by our tax dollars!, go to his equity investing friends for more give aways of giant bonuses paid on our backs, bonuses of Romney-written government checks to people who confuse success with a bailout. He wants to give Wall St. champagne parties while the rest of us are left with crumbs.
Just saw this.  D'accord.

Well, count me as another who just couldn't figure out the theme, though I spent a good 10 minutes at least, after solving the puzzle, trying to figure it out. Eventually, I conceived the horrifying fancy that this was a meta-puzzle and the broken promise WAS that there was any sort of theme uniting the four answers. I quickly dismissed this from my head, but the pernicious idea germinated and took root and finally grew to the point where I could no longer bear to spend any longer on the search for a theme and fled to Wordplay for succor.

Pres Karzai is having best of the both worlds.Keeping the security outsourced to west at their costs and using the  free flow of aid money both accounted and unaccounted to keep his dissenters  mouth  shut including perhaps a moderate wing of Taliban.

I read this apt analogy on the NY HEAL5 technical discussion document

Suppose it was discovered that live music dramatically improved health outcomes. New York rallies and demands live music in every health interaction. However, the musical abilities among our health professionals are limited. The health care community comes up with a technological solution: “we will put a piano in every doctor’s office.” That should solve the problem. But we know that pianos will not solve the problem alone, because, as any musician will tell you, the music is not in the piano.

There is some hyperbole in this story but the essential characteristics are analogous. The benefit is the music or in the information. Electronic health records (EHRs), for example, are essential but not enough to ensure effective use of information and improved health for New Yorkers. An environment must be created and substantial efforts made to ‘get the music from the piano’ or utilize the information and enable clinicians to learn how to consistently realize the benefits from vastly improved availability of health information.
I always thought it was a Victorian Zionist organization rallying cry ... Haifa league, Haifa lieague, Haifa league, onward!

More Monty Python: a poetry society listens to Alfred Lord Tenniscourt read his poem, "The Charge of the Ant Brigade":

"Half an inch, half an inch, half an inch onward!"
LOL, both of you...it's a mercy there's no response from someone suffering from BPH...

I had not heard of ANAPEST before. This puzzle had a lot of easy clues, more than in most Thursday puzzles I've done. I didn't set any speed records, though as I got stumped for a while in the middle top area. Thanks for showing the theme words in the blog, Deb. I did not find them mostly because I forgot to look. Too focused on finishing the puzzle, probably.
If only their own troops could afford to buy the hashish! Though I am not sure it is the drug of choice among the cognoscenti of the Afghan army. Religion seems to have them befuddled enough as is.

Why do we need to care about Afghanistan and how it fares in this purely civil dispute? Why is this our business? While we can have a rooting interest, we need only to resolve to have good relations with whoever comes out on top.

We should remove our people immediately. That whole miserable country and their duplicitous president Hamid "the Hat" Karzai aren't worth the life of even one more American kid.

If their own troops are too stoned on hashish to keep the peace,

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/12/22/afghan-armys-hashish-smok_n_400...

they should hire private security who can get it done. Maybe we can help them with that.
I heard that the Afghans are going to pass a law allowing a single term representative to get a lifetime's worth of medical and pension benefits..... oh sorry that is our government. oops.

The Independent, a well known English paper reported this morning that Hamid Karzai is willing to officially make all Afghan women 'second class citizens' again to help him negotiate with the Taliban. He has backed guidelines by Afghanistan's religious council that relegates women to the positions of second class citizens apparently in the belief that it will help him engage in a peace deal with the Taliban.

I have always been worrieed about the fate of Afghanistan's women when we pull out in 2014 (and the Taliban take over). Now Karzai (supposedly 'our puppet') has done the dirty work for the Taliban. So WHY are we still there?

Nothing new here.  How many times have we seen this headline?  Our invasion of Afghanistan has been a waste on so many levels it's hard to understand who, other than a military contractor, believes it should continue another minute.
The 'Polester' sounds like a plain old monopod that you hold up in the air.  Photo magazines periodically seem to rediscover the monopod.

@Phil from Austin -  I have a severe form of degenerative arthritis in my hands.  A communication/computing device that is light enough for me to handle with a screen big enough to see and touch accurately, HD video camera with image stabilization to hide my shaky hands, and voice recognition for dictation will allow me to share my stories and walks in the forest with the people I love.  That's what makes this iPad great.

Hopefully the U.S. will not get tricked into another conflict, as was the case in Liyba.   First, even as Al Jazeera fed the other media and the world total false new about waht was happening there due to its owner (the head of Qatar) wanting NATO to come in and remove a secular Islamic regime so a strong Sunni regime could be put in place, now in Syria the world is being fed totally false statistics and info.   All media are getting their info from only 2 places, one in Syria and one in London - both of which are working in conjunction with the opposition in Syria.   There is a YouTube video now in which Anderson Cooper is talking with "Danny the Zionist" to get an update in what is going on in Syria.  This man has been a "key contact."   Well, before Copper calls him, Danny tells his associate to turn on the "gunfire" tape...which he does and suddenly gunfire is heard in the background (whereas none was before.)  This is TOTALLY CONTRIVED.  May the U.S. not get drawn into a conflict in which Saudi Arabia and Qatar want only to remove Alawite Muslim Assad to put in a Sunni regime (which they have wanted since 1976) - and which UK, US, and France only want to remove to make Iran easier to take over.
Just under 10 minutes, then another 3 or 4 trying to figure out the theme...  okay, ledge, path, ford and show??  O no.   Faa.  Gimme a gr...  Then, finally,  "d'oh!"  Nicely ideated!
I don't know, but I've been told... that some places in the middle east have executions during half-time at soccer matches, or used to anyway.  Perhaps a warning to aspiring soccer houligans.

In the spirit of parody, this week I found a collection of mid 17th century colonial British political cartoons about America that are as ugly and raw as today's rhetoric--with more point and bite! For a leitmotif, here's a link to several favorites: http://wp.me/p1mBVu-FG.

Compare them to today! See how long obsession with the belief that every government is fraught with irredeemable despairhas been a noble heritage! Note several are sensitive and treat women as objects of violence and pleasure, a historical review of attitudes eeriely similar to today. Religion and myth are there; so are tough guys, open pits (for the failed), hated foreign enemies, wild beasts, and those asleep at the wheel.They are also captioned.

I agree with Nik. I got one for my mom. She had never gotten the hang of her windows laptop. She's achieved independence from my dad's control of the computer. Now she can send email, and surf the web. She leaves it on in the kitchen for recipes. She watches movies on Netflix. She downloads ebooks (free oldies). I even taught her Skype, but she doesn't use it. For an non-techie, it opens up a new world.

The old laptop took a long time to boot up. It spewed mysterious messages about antiviruses. Email was confused and awkward and her mailbox was filled with junk (now she uses gmail via POP on the iPad). It's simple. It works. It doesn't overwhelm non-techies. There's not much to mess up.

:-) its actually 400% better.

No need to throw out, can donate to someone who can't afford a new one.

@PauloMC
The closely followed facts say that austerity is not working in Europe. Can you provide links that prove otherwise?
Just where is Greece supposed to get the money to spend their way out of this?  Would you lend it to them? Austerity is their only way out.

I'd respectfully suggest that, when writing about Goldman Sachs and the complex financial dealings it engaged into with Greece as counterparty, one should speak from a position of knowledge (about specifics of said financial operations); in particular, "currency swaps" were never part of the equation (as far as GS is concerned).

Also: there is no such thing as the "EEU"; there's the "EU" (European Union), and there once was the "EEC", the acronym for what was then the "European Economic Community", which over time gave way to the current EU. There were also the EC (then the European Community; now
the European Commission, a governing body of the current EU), the name given the economic and political confederation of European nations before ratification of the "Treaty of European Union", or "Maastricht Treaty"; as well as the "Eurozone", a subset of the EU, since not all EU member countries adopted the euro as common single currency. But the use of "EEU" as an acronym (standing for "European Economic Union", i reckon) has been proscribed and has long ago fallen into obsoleteness anyway.

. Your depiction of Greece sadly is very accurate. The problem with Greece was not that it was a welfare state but that it was a thoroughly corrupt state. The government was always notoriously underfunded because citizens of all classes either underpaid or did not pay taxes at all. This was particularly egregious with the rich.They had no system for reliable tax collection and for this reason alone Greece should never have been allowed into the EEU.Your depiction of bribery is accurate.

In the 90's when Greece was being considered for the EEU,their treatment of the severely mentally was abominable. The EEU gave them money to improve this situation as a stipulation of admittance and to conform to standards of larger Europe. After a time period, no changes were made, and nobody in the Greek government was able to explain what happen to the money. At least in this instance, Greece was made to pay back the money. I know this because I was living with friends of mine in Athens at the time..

Let us not forget the role of Goldman Sachs in Greece's financial problems. They loaned Greece billions disguised as I think "currency swaps", not loans, so as to make Greece look more solvent to the EEU. Of course, Greece was unable to pay the enormous interest, a major reason in their collapse. As with the bankers in the USA, they are escaping legal culpability as well as being bailed out.

I think entire severe austerity model has more to do with rescuing the banks than Greece itself.

Yeah, how about 7-foot players who can dribble and pass, and 6'2" players who can dunk and rebound.

The downside of this kind of analyis is that if actually realized, we would end up with one-dimensional athletes who can do only one thing well. Like enforcers in hockey, place kickers in football, and designated hitters in baseball.

Basketball among the major sports is the one where mutlidimensional athletes can thrive:dribble, pass, shoot, run, drive, rebound, dunk, and THINK. That is a basketball star. That is your "one of a kind," epitomized by MJ.

What about teaching all the players ALL of the skills that the positions entail.  The Euros have been doing this for years.   We have been hampering our youngsters by not making them all-around BASKETBALL PLAYERS.

Buying eyeglasses in Thailand is decidedly not a bargain. While the price of goods made here is very cheap with low labor costs, there is huge duty with imported items. Most lenses and good frames are not made in Thailand. I have found the prices better in the US. In addition, one is not supporting a corrupt class by paying a premium for imported items. Beijing is much better for eyeglass prices. More difficult to breach the language barrier so bring your script.

Winthrop:

You might be thinking of the public executions in Afghanistan that the Taliban used to stage, sometimes at soccer stadiums.

Public executions have not disappeared altogether. Here are two brief excerpts from Amnesty International reports.

* "In Saudi Arabia, at least 69 people were publicly beheaded during 2009. At the end of 2009, Amnesty International knew of at least 141 people on death row in Saudi Arabia, including at least 104 foreign nationals, mostly from developing countries in Africa, Asia and the Middle East."

* "There were around four times as many public executions in 2011 as in 2010, a practice that Amnesty International said was used by the authorities to strike fear into society."

Mark McDonald

The Arab world already see the U.S. simply wanting to remove Syria's pro-Iranian regime in order to make it easier to remove the current Iranian regime and take over that country.    The Arab world viewed America's involvement in Libya as soley motivated to get control of LIbya's resources, namely its 64.4 billion barrels of high quality sweet light crude oil - and to keep Gaddafi from turning from the dollar to use the African gold dinar in his oil trade (and helping other African nations do the same).  This would have hurt the world banking cartel, so they acted under the guise of "deomcrcy" to remove Gaddafi.

It's been my experience that workers in union environments strongly internalize any adverse change in their work environment. Their union rhetoric is usually heated, relentless, and full of terms like "fight" and "battle". So layoffs and higher workload, which are expected to negatively impact motivation and job satisfaction in any industry, are amplified by the strong sense of grievance and feelings of victimhood.

Wow, JolleyG, I not only admire those who speak foreign languages was such comfort and ease here in WP, but also those who can breeze through to the finish in times I can only marvel at.
Despite the fact that I sorely lack the educational credentials that my friends here accumulated throughout their lives, they've nevertheless made me feel so welcomed to sit at their table and have never treated me like I was some kind of hired stable boy, somewhat akin to a Emily Bronte Heathcliff character.
Thank goodness, that nary a holier-than-thou type inhales the same air within these wonderfully wordy hallowed chambers!

Good night, my dear non-condescending friends of WP

WHH

I was done before I thought of looking for a theme. I don't like themes that aren't integral to solving the puzzle.

ANAPEST was a new one on me. Fortunately all the crosses were easy. You could have told me it was the German version of an Italian salad or an Anabaptist dissenter.
